conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the difference in displacement between two objects, A and B, during the time interval from 0 to t₁ based on their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.

The v-t graphs show two curves: the upper curve represents object A, and the lower curve represents object B. Both curves start at the origin (0,0), peak, and return to v = 0 at t₁. The curves appear to be parabolas.
The area under a v-t curve represents the displacement of an object.

premise: The area under a v-t curve represents displacement. The upper curve corresponds to object A, and the lower curve corresponds to object B.
conclusion: The difference in displacement between objects A and B at any time t is the area between the two curves from 0 to t.

premise: The difference in displacement between objects A and B at any time t is the area between the two curves from 0 to t.
conclusion: Let Δs(t) = s_A(t) - s_B(t), where s_A(t) and s_B(t) are the displacements of objects A and B, respectively. Δs(t) represents the difference in displacement at time t.
To determine if Δs(t) is continuously increasing, its derivative with respect to time must be positive: dΔs(t)/dt > 0 for all t in [0, t₁].
From the graph, at t = 0, both objects start with v = 0. For all t between 0 and t₁, the upper curve (v_A) is always above the lower curve (v_B). At t = t₁, both velocities return to 0.

premise: From the graph, v_A(t) > v_B(t) for all t in (0, t₁).
conclusion: Since v_A(t) > v_B(t) for all t in (0, t₁), the derivative of Δs(t) is always positive in this interval.

premise: The derivative of Δs(t) is always positive in the interval (0, t₁).
conclusion: The difference in displacement Δs(t) is continuously increasing during the interval [0, t₁].

premise: The difference in displacement Δs(t) is continuously increasing during the interval [0, t₁].
conclusion: Yes, the difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t₁.
